verses.text: Now one day Jonathan the son of Saul said to the young man who carried his armor, “Come, let’s go over to the Philistine garrison that is on the other side.” But he did not tell his father.
verses.comment: “Armorbearer” reflects the Hebrew word used for Jonathan’s companion.

verses.text: Saul was staying on the outskirts of Gibeah under the pomegranate tree at Migron. The people with him were about six hundred men,
verses.comment: “Migron” is retained from the Hebrew for location.

verses.text: and Ahijah the son of Ahitub, Ichabod’s brother, son of Phinehas, son of Eli, the priest of the LORD at Shiloh, was wearing the ephod. The people did not know that Jonathan had left.
verses.comment: “Ephod” refers to the priestly garment used for seeking God’s guidance.

verses.text: Between the passes, by which Jonathan aimed to go over to the Philistines’ outpost, there was a rocky crag on one side and a rocky crag on the other. The name of the one was Bozez, and the name of the other Seneh.
verses.comment: Bozez and Seneh are transliterated from Hebrew as place names.

verses.text: One crag rose on the north in front of Michmash, the other on the south in front of Geba.
verses.comment: Locations retained from the original; geographical direction clarified.

verses.text: Jonathan said to the young man who carried his armor, “Come, let’s cross over to the outpost of these uncircumcised. Perhaps the LORD will act for us, for nothing restrains the LORD from saving by many or by few.”
verses.comment: “Uncircumcised” is a literal translation, referring to non-Israelites.

verses.text: His armorbearer said to him, “Do all that you have in mind. I am with you heart and soul.”
verses.comment: “Heart and soul” is a dynamic but clear rendering of Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Then Jonathan said, “Look, we’ll cross over to the men and show ourselves to them.
verses.comment: Words closely reflect the original Hebrew intention.

verses.text: If they say to us, ‘Wait until we come to you,’ then we will stand still in our place and not go up to them.
verses.comment: Conditional statement retained clearly from the Hebrew.

verses.text: But if they say, ‘Come up to us,’ then we will go up, for the LORD has given them into our hand. This will be the sign to us.”
verses.comment: ‘Sign’ translated from Hebrew ‘ot’ as a sign or confirmation.

verses.text: So both of them revealed themselves to the Philistine outpost, and the Philistines said, “Look, the Hebrews are coming out of the holes where they’ve been hiding.”
verses.comment: “Holes” refers to hiding places, caves, etc.

verses.text: And the men of the outpost called out to Jonathan and his armorbearer, “Come up to us, and we will show you something!” So Jonathan said to his armorbearer, “Come up after me, for the LORD has given them into Israel’s hand.”
verses.comment: Phrase “show you something” reflects biblical language for threatening.

verses.text: Jonathan climbed up on his hands and feet, with his armorbearer following him. And the Philistines fell before Jonathan, and his armorbearer killed after him.
verses.comment: Climbing “on his hands and feet” clarifies the difficulty of the approach.

verses.text: In that first attack, Jonathan and his armorbearer killed about twenty men, within about half a furrow’s length in an acre of land.
verses.comment: “Half a furrow’s length in an acre” is literally translated; ancient measurement.

verses.text: Then panic spread throughout the camp, in the field, and among all the people. The outpost and the raiders were trembling, and the earth quaked, and it became a very great panic.
verses.comment: Earthquake described literally as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Saul’s watchmen in Gibeah of Benjamin saw the multitude dispersing in every direction.
verses.comment: “Watchmen” refers to the scouts or lookouts.

verses.text: Saul said to the people who were with him, “Call the roll and see who has gone from us.” When they called the roll, Jonathan and his armorbearer were not there.
verses.comment: Phrase “call the roll” is used for counting; literally means to number.

verses.text: So Saul said to Ahijah, “Bring the ark of God here.” For the ark of God was at that time with the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts read ‘ephod’ rather than ‘ark’; here ‘ark’ reflects the Masoretic Text.

verses.text: While Saul was speaking to the priest, the tumult in the Philistine camp kept increasing. So Saul said to the priest, “Withdraw your hand.”
verses.comment: ‘Withdraw your hand’ refers to stopping priestly ritual consultation.

verses.text: Then Saul and all the people with him rallied and went into the battle, and there was great confusion. Every Philistine’s sword was against his fellow, and there was very great disorder.
verses.comment: Description of chaos matches the original.

verses.text: The Hebrews who had been with the Philistines before and who had gone up with them into the camp, even they turned to join the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
verses.comment: Hebrew deserters return in battle; ‘Hebrews’ is the original term.

verses.text: Likewise, all the men of Israel who had hidden themselves in the hill country of Ephraim heard that the Philistines were fleeing, so they joined in the pursuit in battle.
verses.comment: “Hill country of Ephraim” retains original geography.

verses.text: So the LORD saved Israel that day, and the battle passed beyond Beth-aven.
verses.comment: “Saved Israel” is a direct translation of Hebrew ‘yasha.’

verses.text: Now the men of Israel were hard pressed that day, because Saul had put an oath on the people, saying, “Cursed be the man who eats food before evening, until I have taken vengeance on my enemies.” So none of the people tasted any food.
verses.comment: Saul’s oath rendered directly; ‘cursed be the man’ is literal.

verses.text: Now all the land had come into the forest, and there was honey on the ground.
verses.comment: The literal wording “honey on the ground” is retained.

verses.text: When the people entered the forest and saw the honey dripping, none of them put his hand to his mouth, for they feared the oath.
verses.comment: Literal phrasing from the Hebrew.

verses.text: But Jonathan had not heard when his father put the people under oath, so he reached out with the end of the stick in his hand, dipped it in the honeycomb, and put his hand to his mouth. His eyes brightened.
verses.comment: “His eyes brightened” literally translates Hebrew idiom for renewed strength.

verses.text: Then one of the people said, “Your father strictly charged the people with an oath, saying, ‘Cursed be the man who eats any food this day.’ So the people are weak.”
verses.comment: “Strictly charged” conveys the Hebrew sense of strong order.

verses.text: Jonathan said, “My father has troubled the land. See, my eyes have brightened because I tasted a little of this honey.
verses.comment: “Troubled” translates the literal Hebrew phrasing for bringing trouble.

verses.text: How much better if the people had eaten freely today of the spoil taken from their enemies! For now the slaughter among the Philistines has not been great.”
verses.comment: Reasoning from Jonathan preserved close to Hebrew structure.

verses.text: They struck down the Philistines that day from Michmash to Aijalon. The people were very faint.
verses.comment: Geographical details preserved; ‘faint’ is literal for exhaustion.

verses.text: The people rushed upon the spoil, took sheep and oxen and calves, slaughtered them on the ground, and ate them with the blood.
verses.comment: Eating with blood is prohibited in Hebrew law; word order preserved.

verses.text: Then someone reported to Saul, “Look, the people are sinning against the LORD by eating with the blood.” Saul said, “You have acted unfaithfully. Roll a large stone to me here.”
verses.comment: “Unfaithfully” translates Hebrew word for acting treacherously.

verses.text: Saul declared, “Disperse yourselves among the people and tell them, ‘Let every man bring his ox or sheep and slaughter it here and eat. Don’t sin against the LORD by eating with the blood.’” That night, all the people brought their animals and slaughtered them there.
verses.comment: The instructions are rendered literally; “don’t sin against the LORD” is direct from Hebrew.

verses.text: Saul built an altar to the LORD; it was the first altar he had built to the LORD.
verses.comment: Altar-building noted as first for Saul; direct translation.

verses.text: Then Saul said, “Let’s go down after the Philistines by night and plunder them until morning light. Let us not leave a man of them.” And they replied, “Do whatever seems good to you.” But the priest said, “Let us draw near to God here.”
verses.comment: “Draw near” retains the sense of seeking God’s guidance or prayer.

verses.text: So Saul asked God, “Shall I go down after the Philistines? Will you give them into Israel’s hand?” But He did not answer him that day.
verses.comment: Question to God rendered as literal prayer/inquiry.

verses.text: And Saul said, “Come here, all you leaders of the people, and know and see how this sin has happened today.”
verses.comment: “Leaders” translates the Hebrew ‘cornerstones’ or ‘chiefs.’

verses.text: For as the LORD lives, who saves Israel, even if the offense is in Jonathan my son, he shall surely die.” But none of all the people answered him.
verses.comment: As the LORD lives” is a faithful translation of the Hebrew oath formula.

verses.text: Then he said to all Israel, “You be on one side, and I and Jonathan my son will be on the other side.” And the people said to Saul, “Do what seems good to you.”
verses.comment: Division for lots is stated clearly.

verses.text: Then Saul said to the LORD, the God of Israel, “Give a perfect lot.” And Jonathan and Saul were taken by lot, but the people escaped.
verses.comment: ‘Perfect lot’ is a literal rendering of Hebrew. Some LXX manuscripts expand this verse, but the Masoretic text is followed.

verses.text: Saul said, “Cast lots between me and Jonathan my son.” And Jonathan was taken.
verses.comment: Casting lots for guilt is preserved; direct translation.

verses.text: Then Saul said to Jonathan, “Tell me what you have done.” And Jonathan answered him, “I tasted a little honey with the staff that was in my hand. Here I am; I must die.”
verses.comment: Jonathan’s confession is preserved in original form.

verses.text: Saul said, “May God do so and more also; you shall surely die, Jonathan.”
verses.comment: Formulaic oath “may God do so and more” retained.

verses.text: But the people said to Saul, “Shall Jonathan die, who has worked this great deliverance in Israel? Far from it! As the LORD lives, not one hair of his head shall fall to the ground, for he has worked with God this day.” So the people rescued Jonathan, so that he was not put to death.
verses.comment: “Not one hair…” is a direct Hebrew idiom, expressing total protection.

verses.text: Then Saul went up from pursuing the Philistines, and the Philistines went to their own place.
verses.comment: Retains literal division and conclusion of battle.

verses.text: After Saul had taken the kingdom over Israel, he fought against all his enemies on every side: Moab, the Ammonites, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. Wherever he turned, he routed them.
verses.comment: Summary of Saul’s reign rendered as in the original.

verses.text: He acted valiantly and struck the Amalekites, and delivered Israel out of the hands of those who plundered them.
verses.comment: “Valiantly” comes from Hebrew for “did mighty deeds.”

verses.text: Now the sons of Saul were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malchi-shua. The names of his two daughters were Merab, the firstborn, and Michal, the younger.
verses.comment: Names transliterated directly from Hebrew; Ishvi called ‘Ishbosheth’ elsewhere.

verses.text: The name of Saul’s wife was Ahinoam the daughter of Ahimaaz. The name of the commander of his army was Abner son of Ner, Saul’s uncle.
verses.comment: Family relationships and names are preserved.

verses.text: Kish was the father of Saul, and Ner the father of Abner was the son of Abiel.
verses.comment: Genealogical detail retained, direct translation.

verses.text: Saul fought hard against the Philistines all his days. Whenever Saul saw any strong or brave man, he attached him to himself.
verses.comment: Summary of Saul’s recruitment policy; literal translation.
